metadata.titleEn: Multi-frequency and multi-angular ground-based microwave radiometer and radar cooperative experimental data for grassland in 2018
metadata.description:
This data set was collected in 2018 during the ground-based microwave radiometry and radar cooperative experiment, which is part of the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River (SMELR). The experiment site is located in Zhenglan Banner, Inner Mongolia (115.93° E, 42.04° N, at 1362 m in altitude). The data set contains four parts, namely brightness temperature data, radar backscatter coefficient, soil data and vegetation data. The microwave brightness temperature data was observed by a vehicle-mounted dual-polarized multi-frequency radiometer (RPG-6CH-DP), including the horizontal (H) and vertical (V) polarization brightness temperatures at L-, C- and X-bands.  The brightness temperature data was acquired every 30 minutes from 30° to 65° with an interval of 2.5°. The active microwave data is obtained by ground-based synthetic aperture radar (GBSAR), including the L- and C-band backscattering coefficients under four polarization modes (VV, VH, HH, HV), and the incidence varies from 30° to 65° (2.5° interval). The soil data contains the surface roughness, soil moisture and temperature at six depths of layer (1 cm, 3 cm, 5 cm, 10 cm, 20 cm, 50 cm). The vegetation data is mainly the vegetation water content of the grassland.
The experimental period lasted from August 18 to September 25, 2018, and it provided important data for the land surface microwave radiation modeling and validation, as well as the development of soil moisture retrieval algorithms.
metadata.instructions:
The data file is saved in xlsx format and is named as: ZhenglanqiExp+ '_ParaName'. 'ParaName' represents the abbreviation of the observed parameter. For example, the brightness temperature is named as 'ZhenglanqiExp_TB.xlsx', the soil data set is named as 'ZhenglanqiExp_Soil.xlsx' .
Data reading method: The data set can be directly opened with Excel.

background: Due to the success of the SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) and SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive) missions, new satellite missions are on the horizon. The current and future missions can benefit from investigations that seek to improve retrieval algorithms that quantitatively map global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth (tau) from Earth’s microwave emissions.
research objective: In this study, we explore multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches for the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation tau, considering the payload configurations of current and future satellite missions (such as the Copernicus Imaging Microwave Radiometer, the Water Cycle Observation Mission, and the Terrestrial Water Resources Satellite) using a new set of ground observations.
challenges: It is affirmed that increasing the number of observation channels could make the soil moisture retrieval more robust, but might also limit the retrieval performance, as the probability that the model estimations will not match the observations is increased.
methods: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study. A multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is developed based on the two-component version of the omega-tau model, which utilizes information from collaborative channels expressed as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to rule out the parameters to be retrieved.
dataset: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study.
findings: Results of soil moisture retrieval show that the multi-angular approach used by the MCCA generally has a better performance, unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) varying from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³, than the multi-frequency approach (ubRMSD from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.089 cm³/cm³) for the corn field. Except for in the C- & X-band combination, the multi-frequency approach used by the MCCA performs better (ubRMSD from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³) than the multi-angular version (ubRMSD from 0.026 cm³/cm³ to 0.034 cm³/cm³) for the grass field due to reduced vegetation effects for this type of cover. This study provides new insights into the design of potential satellite missions to improve soil moisture retrieval. A satellite with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is highly recommended.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of a dataset that includes both soil moisture measurements and vegetation data for the purpose of microwave emission modeling.
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset comes from the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River, which includes soil moisture data across six soil layers, soil surface roughness, and vegetation water content data. The dataset was collected in Inner Mongolia during the summer of 2018 and provides critical information for microwave emission modeling and algorithm validation.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate a challenge encountered in the development of retrieval algorithms for soil moisture from multi-angular and multi-frequency microwave data?
Example.Answer: A challenge encountered is the potential mismatch between model estimations and observations when increasing the number of observation channels. While additional channels can make soil moisture retrieval more robust, they can also limit retrieval performance. This is due to the complexity introduced by multiple channels, which may increase the probability of discrepancies between model estimations and the actual observations.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches' in microwave radiometry data collection?
Definition.Answer: Multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches in microwave radiometry data collection involve using different angles of incidence and multiple microwave frequency bands to collect data. This approach can help improve the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth by providing more robust data through diverse observation channels.

Definition.Question: What does 'multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA)' mean in the context of soil moisture retrieval?
Definition.Answer: A multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) in soil moisture retrieval is a method that utilizes data from multiple observation channels to estimate soil moisture more accurately. It operates by expressing brightness temperature in an analytical form at a core channel to eliminate parameters that need to be retrieved, thus improving the robustness and performance of soil moisture estimation.

Comparison.Question: In terms of dataset compilation, how does the inclusion of soil and vegetation data enhance the modeling and validation of land surface microwave emission and scattering compared to datasets that exclude these parameters?
Comparison.Answer: The inclusion of soil and vegetation data, such as soil surface roughness, soil moisture, soil temperature at multiple depths, and vegetation water content, provides important ancillary information that enhances modeling and validation of land surface microwave emission and scattering. This comprehensive data supports the development and validation of soil moisture retrieval algorithms and improves the understanding of microwave interactions with the land surface.

Interpretation.Question: How do multi-frequency and multi-angular observations impact the robustness and limitations of soil moisture retrieval in grassland environments?
Interpretation.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels can enhance the robustness of soil moisture retrieval but may also challenge retrieval performance due to potential mismatches between model estimations and observations. The multi-angular approach generally performs better for soil moisture retrieval in certain crop fields, while the multi-frequency approach may yield superior results in grasslands due to reduced vegetation effects.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when using ground-based microwave radiometry datasets to model soil moisture and vegetation parameters across different terrains?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include ensuring that the retrieval algorithms are robust across different terrains and managing the limitations introduced by increasing observation channels, which may lead to discrepancies between model estimations and actual observations. Terrain-specific factors such as vegetation cover can also influence the performance of retrieval approaches.

Interpretation.Question: How can data collection methods be optimized to improve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrievals for future satellite missions?
Interpretation.Answer: Data collection methods can be optimized by employing multi-angular and multi-frequency observations, which have shown potential in improving retrieval performance. Designing satellite missions with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is recommended to enhance soil moisture retrieval, considering the varying effects of vegetation and terrain on these measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches in soil moisture and vegetation retrieval methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need arises from the objective to enhance retrieval algorithms for mapping global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from Earth's microwave emissions, as these approaches can provide more robust data and reduce the limitations of retrieval performance by utilizing multiple observation channels.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might increasing the number of observation channels in a dataset affect the performance of soil moisture retrieval?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels could potentially make soil moisture retrieval more robust by providing diverse data points, but it might also introduce challenges where model estimations may not match observations, thereby limiting retrieval performance.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using multi-frequency and multi-angular approaches in the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from microwave emissions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of multi-angular approaches generally results in better performance for soil moisture retrieval in certain field types, such as corn fields, with unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) varying from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³. However, for grass fields, the multi-frequency approach performs better with ubRMSD from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³, due to reduced vegetation effects.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of multiple observation channels impact the robustness and limitations of soil moisture retrieval models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels could enhance the robustness of soil moisture retrieval models, but it might also limit retrieval performance, as the probability of discrepancies between model estimations and observations increases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to use a multi-channel collaborative algorithm for retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from ground-based observations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using a multi-channel collaborative algorithm is important because it can enhance the robustness of soil moisture retrieval by utilizing information from collaborative channels, thereby potentially improving the performance of retrieval algorithms for current and future satellite missions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are used to integrate both passive and active microwave observations for the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation properties?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The integration of passive and active microwave observations involves using ground-based instruments such as microwave radiometers and radar systems. The passive microwave data, specifically brightness temperatures at multiple frequencies and polarizations, are collected using instruments like the RPG-6CH-DP microwave radiometer. Active microwave data are obtained using ground-based radar to measure backscatter coefficients at various polarizations. These datasets are used in a multi-channel collaborative algorithm to improve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrievals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How do researchers address the challenges of increased observation channels potentially limiting retrieval performance?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Researchers recognize that while increasing the number of observation channels can enhance the robustness of soil moisture retrieval, it may also increase the risk of model estimations not matching observations. To address this challenge, they develop algorithms like the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA), which uses information from collaborative channels to analytically express brightness temperature, helping to refine the parameters for retrieval and mitigate the limitations posed by multiple channels.

Enablement.Question: What are the key technological advancements that enable the acquisition of multi-angular and multi-frequency ground-based microwave observations for soil moisture and vegetation studies?
Enablement.Answer: The use of multi-frequency, multi-angular ground-based microwave radiometers and radars, such as the RPG-6CH-DP vehicle-mounted microwave radiometer and ground-based radar (GBSAR), enables the collection of detailed data across different microwave bands and polarizations, with adjustable observation angles, which are crucial for soil moisture and vegetation studies.

Enablement.Question: How do collaborative algorithms enhance the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval using microwave radiometry datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Collaborative algorithms like the Multi-Channel Collaborative Algorithm (MCCA) improve the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval by utilizing information from multiple observation channels, which helps to analytically determine the parameters to be retrieved, thus potentially increasing the robustness of the retrievals.

Enablement.Question: What are the conditions and challenges in using multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches for soil moisture retrieval in varying types of land cover, such as cropland and grassland?
Enablement.Answer: The conditions and challenges include ensuring that the increased number of observation channels does not lead to mismatches between model estimations and observations. Different land covers, such as cropland and grassland, may have varying effects on retrieval accuracy, with vegetation effects being more pronounced in croplands, thus requiring careful consideration of observation configurations.

Expectation.Question: What challenges might arise when increasing the number of observation channels in microwave radiometry, and why might these challenges impact expected outcomes?
Expectation.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels could make soil moisture retrieval more robust; however, it might also introduce challenges by increasing the probability that model estimations will not match the observations. This discrepancy arises because a higher number of channels can complicate the retrieval process, leading to potential mismatches between the model's predictions and the actual data, thus affecting expected outcomes.

Expectation.Question: Why might a simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capability be recommended for future satellite missions aimed at improving soil moisture retrieval?
Expectation.Answer: A satellite with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is recommended because it can potentially provide a comprehensive dataset that leverages the strengths of both approaches. This capability is expected to improve soil moisture retrieval by mitigating the limitations of using either approach in isolation, thus enhancing the accuracy and reliability of the data collected for various surface conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of multi-angular and multi-frequency data collection methods in enhancing soil moisture retrieval accuracy in grassland environments?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of multi-angular and multi-frequency data collection methods in enhancing soil moisture retrieval accuracy in grassland environments can be evaluated based on findings that suggest the multi-frequency approach generally performs better due to reduced vegetation effects, with an unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³, compared to the multi-angular approach.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in using multi-channel collaborative algorithms (MCCA) for soil moisture retrieval in diverse land cover types?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges in using multi-channel collaborative algorithms (MCCA) for soil moisture retrieval in diverse land cover types include the increased complexity due to adding observation channels, which might limit retrieval performance as the probability that model estimations do not match observations increases.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could ground-based microwave radiometry datasets from Inner Mongolia contribute to the advancement of retrieval algorithms for future satellite missions?
Judgmental.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometry datasets from Inner Mongolia could contribute to the advancement of retrieval algorithms for future satellite missions by providing empirical data that supports the development of multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches, thereby offering insights into designing satellites with capabilities that improve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced when increasing the number of observation channels in microwave radiometry for soil moisture retrieval.
Assertion.Answer: Increasing the number of observation channels in microwave radiometry can make soil moisture retrieval more robust. However, it may also pose challenges as it increases the probability that model estimations will not match the observations, potentially limiting retrieval performance.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why a dataset collected from multi-frequency microwave radiometry would be beneficial for developing future satellite missions.
Assertion.Answer: A dataset collected from multi-frequency microwave radiometry is beneficial for developing future satellite missions because it provides valuable insights into the effectiveness of multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches in soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval. This information is crucial for designing satellite missions with enhanced capabilities for simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observations, improving global soil moisture mapping.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an analysis of the methodological approaches used in developing retrieval algorithms for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth, considering collaborative channels in microwave radiometry.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodological approach involves using a multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) based on the two-component version of the omega-tau model. This approach uses information from collaborative channels expressed as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to identify parameters for retrieval. The approach aims to improve soil moisture retrieval by leveraging multi-angular and multi-frequency data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets that can be utilized for validating soil moisture retrieval algorithms using multi-angular and multi-frequency microwave radiometry, beyond those collected in Inner Mongolia.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for validating soil moisture retrieval algorithms could include those collected from satellite missions like SMOS and SMAP, which provide global coverage of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth. These datasets can complement ground-based observations, like those from the Luan River experiments, to provide a comprehensive validation framework.
